column1: Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is a progressive, debilitating, and deadly brain disorder related to measles (rubeola) infection.
SSPE tends to occur several years after an individual has measles, even though the person seems to have fully recovered from the illness.
The disease generally occurs in children and adolescents.

Symptoms may include: - Bizarre behavior - Dementia (loss of mental, emotional, and social abilities) - Coma - Gradual behavioral changes - Myoclonic jerking (quick muscle jerking or spasms) - School problems - Seizures - Unsteady gait - Very tense muscles or muscles that lack tone, with weakness in both legs
There may be a history of measles in an unvaccinated child.

A physical examination may reveal: - Damage to the optic nerve, which is responsible for sight - Damage to the retina, the part of the eye that receives light - Muscle twitching - Poor performance on motor (movement) coordination tests The following tests may be performed: - Electroencephalogram (EEG) - Brain MRI - Serum antibody titer to look for signs of previous measles infection - Spinal tap
People with this disease frequently die 1 to 2 years after diagnosis, but some may survive for longer periods.
The measles vaccine is included in the MMR vaccine.
Immunization against measles is the only known prevention for SSPE.
